TopicTitle: [1.0] WWII Aircraft: Accepting Requests (United Aces of Jeb)

Articles.Content:
![world-war-ii-special-512.jpg](http://buildyourlibrary.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/world-war-ii-special-512.jpg)
From the Untied Aces of Jebediah; engineering corps comes the WWII series, a group of interesting and iconic aircraft from the great global conflict in the 1940's involving the Allies and the Axis powers. So far I have the Yokosuka MXY-7 Ohka Model 22, a jet propelled Japanese kamikaze suicide attack plane built towards the end of World War 2; the Heinkel HE-162, a Luftwaffe jet fighter built late in the war; the Horton HO-229, the first stealth bomber, 3 were built by the Luftwaffe in 1944; the Messerschmitt ME-163 Komet, a German rocket-powered interceptor, it protected key locations under German occupancy; the Messerschmitt ME-262 Swallow, the first ever operational fighter jet, it was the cause of 542 allied kills; the Bachem Ba-349 a rocket powered interceptor like the ME-163 with and Interesting landing procedure; the Arado Ar-234, the first operational jet bomber; the Heinkel He-176, the first aircraft to be powered solely by a liquid-fueled rocket; the Northrop XP-79B, an experimental flying wing aircraft with was destroyed during its first flight; the de Havilland Vampire, was a British fighter jet manufactured during the war by de Havilland, 3,300 were produced; the Gloster E.28/39, was the first British jet-engine powered aircraft to actually fly; the Bell P-59 Airacomet, was a proposed jet fighter in the U.S. during WWII it was canceled because the USAF was not impressed with its performance; the Hawker Siddeley Sea Hawk was a British naval fighter, 542 were built (Coincidence? I think not); the Lockheed P-80 Shooting Star, was the first jet fighter used operationally by the United States Air Force, 1,715 were built; the Dassault Ouragan, was the first French-designed jet fighter/bomber to enter production and active service; the Yokosuka MXY-7 Ohka model 11, was a rocket-propelled Japanese suicide bomber during WW2; the Grumman F9F Panther, was Grumman's first jet fighter and one of the U.S. Navy's first successful aircraft carrier-based jet fighters. I am currently working on the Sud-Ouest SO.6000, and the Heinkel He-178. Any suggestions and feedback would be appreciated. Also if you want me to use KAX to make prop planes show your support and if enough people like the idea I will.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-07-06T19:43:19Z" title="07/06/2015 07:43  PM" data-short="9 yr">July 6, 2015</time> by Ace\_Of\_Spades**

I believe the Ohka was propelled by solid rocket motors. It was dropped from a bomber mothership, after which it would glide down to its target, and ignite the rocket engine for the final plunge towards the target. 

So it was basically a glider with a little rocket engine. Separatrons should work nicely for this.

I thouht that the Ohka was solid! A "Sandy" would drop it, it would glide, and use the booster for a massive boost to destruction! A flea booster would work. Or, you could make it smaller with Sepertions.

Looks good though, nice work!

- - - Updated - - -

Oh, Long-term Nin'jd

> 
> I believe the Ohka was propelled by solid rocket motors. It was dropped from a bomber mothership, after which it would glide down to its target, and ignite the rocket engine for the final plunge towards the target. 
> So it was basically a glider with a little rocket engine. Separatrons should work nicely for this.

All of the other models besides the 22 had rocket engines, the 22 used a jet engine; And to simulate dropping it from the plane I lifted it high up on launch towers.

xf-11? maybe, using kax?

It isn't a Word War II aircraft, but I see a few other aircraft in this thread that didn't see combat service until korea, including the F-82 (Oops, that was my own request), so what about the Grumman F9F Panther? I haven't seen a good replica of it yet.

Come to think of it, I haven't seen any replicas of it yet.
A Messerschmitt me 323 would be really cool to see in ksp.
